thread.title: Plainfield South football dominates on all levels in win over Central
thread.title_full: Plainfield South football dominates on all levels in win over Central

title: Plainfield South football dominates on all levels in win over Central
text:
Plainfield South football dominates on all levels in win over Central Published: Friday, Oct. 16, 2015 10:57 p.m. CDT Caption (Eric Ginnard - eginnard@shawmedia.com) Plainfield South's Mitchell Ganassin disrupts a long pass from Plainfield Central's offense Friday at Plainfield South High School in Joliet. The Cougars beat the Wildcats, 49-7. By SCOTT EHLING - Shaw Media Correspondent 
JOLIET – Plainfield South scored on three of its first four offensive possessions, jumped out to a 28-0 first quarter lead, extended it to 49-0 at half and never looked back en route to a 49-7 victory over visiting Plainfield Central in the Southwest Prairie Conference action Friday night. Related Links Plainfield North has no trouble with Romeoville 
The Cougars scored in all three phases, while the South defense forced two turnovers, had two quarterback sacks and allowed Central just 92 total yards of offense. Fifteen of Central’s 25 running plays were for either zero or negative yards. 
Offensively, the Cougars (5-3, 5-1) were led by senior running back Jake Maher, senior running back Danny Saracco, junior quarterback Nicholas Deppe and senior wideout Christian Carrillo. Maher had seven rushes for 67 yards; Saracco had three rushes for 39 yards and two touchdowns; Deppe was 6-of-8 passing for 120 yards and a touchdown; and Carillo had four receptions for 94 yards and a touchdown. 
Junior defensive back Joseph Yanke had a 40-yard interception return for touchdown and Mitchell Ganassin had a 50-yard punt return for touchdown. 
Junior quarterback Cameron Cercone led the Wildcats (0-8, 0-6) by going 6-of-21 passing for 91 yards and a touchdown. Teammate Nathaniel Graves had two catches for 57 yards and a touchdown. 
“We had the right formula for success tonight,” Plainfield South coach Ken Bublitz said. “Our defense set the tone early and we gained momentum as the game went on.”
